data.sampled: The option strategy you have described can be classified as an "iron condor". This strategy involves selling a higher-strike and lower-strike options (the put spread), while simultaneously buying another set of options with different strike prices but the same underlying asset (the call spread). The goal of this strategy is to make a profit from both sides of the trade by taking advantage of pricing imbalances or time decay. However, it also carries risk if the stock moves significantly in either direction before expiration.

Current stock price $46.84, Sell 1 $42 strike price put at $1.28. Buy 1 $40 strike price put at $0.85. Sell 1 $47 strike price call at $0.86. Buy 1 $48 strike price call at $0.57.

data.sampled: This is an Iron Condor options trading strategy. The trader has sold one out-of-the money (OTM) put and bought another OTM put at a lower strike price to create a credit spread, while simultaneously selling an ITM call and buying another OTM call at a higher strike price to also create a debit spread. By doing this, they aim to profit from time decay on both sides of their position, as long as the stock doesn't move too far away from either set of strikes before expiration. If it does, the losses could be significant.

data.sampled: The name of the option strategy being implemented here is a Bull Put Spread. This involves selling an out-of-the money (OTM) put and buying a further OTM put to create a net credit received from the sale. It also involves purchasing an ITM call and writing another call that has a higher strike price but a lower premium than the purchased one, resulting in a net debit paid on this trade.

data.sampled: The name of the option strategy being implemented is a bull put spread and bear call spread combination. This involves selling a higher-strike price put (bearish) while simultaneously buying a lower-strike price put (bullish), along with selling a higher-strike price call (bearish) while simultaneously buying a lower-strike price call (bullish). This strategy is often used to generate income through premium received from selling options while potentially limiting losses if the underlying stock moves against your position.

data.sampled: Long Put Butterfly Spread (Long Straddle). This is an options trading strategy that involves buying and selling different types of options contracts to reduce risk while still benefiting from potential price movements. The trader has bought two puts with lower strike prices ($90) and sold two calls with higher strike prices ($105 and $110), creating a net credit received on entry. If the stock price moves significantly up or down by expiration date, this trade will be profitable. However, if it stays within the range between the strikes of both puts and calls, there may not be any profit made.

Assume all contracts are for 100 shares. Answer with no explanation, only a classification. data.sampled: The option strategy being implemented here is called an Iron Condor. This strategy involves selling two options (put and/or call) that have higher strike prices and buying two other options with lower strike prices to create a spread. In this case, it appears that the trader has sold one out-of-the-money (OTM) put and bought another OTM put, while also selling an ITM call and buying another ITM call. The goal is usually to collect premium income from both sides of the trade, while limiting risk on each side by using different strikes.

data.sampled: This is an example of a Bull Put Spread. A bullish options strategy that involves buying one out-of-the money (OTM) put and selling another OTM put with a higher exercise/strike price, or shorting stock equal to the difference between both puts' prices, thus limiting potential losses while keeping some upside exposure.
